div.head: To the Right Honorable the Lord Major and Aldermen of the City of London.
The Remonſtrance and Petition of Thomas Church Eſq;
div.p:
THat your Petitioner having ſetled himſelfe at the firſt on your Plantations in Ʋlſter, was long imployed by ſome of your chiefe Corporations had intereſt therein, though the ill carriage of your grand Agent, Mr. Berisford, much hindred that ſervice, who to work himſelfe into favour with thoſe that there then ruled in chiefe, At the firſt let ſlip with Eniſhowne, ſome two thouſand Acres of Land, after the Kings then accuſtomed Survey, that ſhould have belonged to Derry, with ſome thouſand Acres more from Colraine, together with the Rights and Priviledges thereto belonging; and ſuffered your Rents, Woods, and Fiſhings to bee common to all pleaſed him: Beſides the innumerable ſtore there of his Ironworkes ſpent and deſtroyed, and all to gaine to himſelfe and friends great bargains of your beſt profits and Revenues there (wherein ſome here was ſurely to blame) which others perceiving, got whole proportions from your moſt diſcontented Corporations at ſuch underrates, as brought this magnificent City of London, in ſo mean and ſlight eſteeme, with ſome that could not ſcrue themſelves into the like, brought caviling ſuits in his Majeſties Name againſt you and thoſe ſtood for your Rights, that for a long time, little of thoſe Rents was paid, but by the extreameſt meanes, wherein I had periſhed and all mine, had not the Right Worſhipfull Company of Mercers born us out in all juſt wayes, as the Worſhipfull Company of Vintners did, to whom I gave all due ſatisfaction; But your vaſt Arreares of ſome ten thouſand pounds, wat ſo long before I had to doe therewith, that I could doe ſmall good therein, till your troubles and the Sequeſtration thereof ſtopped the ſame to the loſſe of all, with ſore Charges, Fines, and Diſpleaſures. The which that all undertakers, and Adventurers may prevent in time to come, cauſeth mee, as in duty bound, to preſent unto your Worthy conſiderations, theſe Propoſitions, for the eſtabliſhing ſuch a government there, that may timely meet with all manner of inconveniencies for the good and ſafety of all Britaine,
as well as it, And regaining your own, in a faire and honourable way, with all forfeited by that Rebellion, to you and your ſeverall Corporations. And as the ſaid Mr. Berisfords over-ruling in peace proved deſtructive, ſo it continued, by his not cauſing the Britiſh to entirely riſe as I moſt earneſtly deſired, at the firſt to ſuppreſſe that rebellion, which had been moſt caſie to do, but ſuffered his Son Michael an Eſquire, with his ſiſter the Lady Cook, To leave that ſtrong Caſtle of Dongivin, As Henry Conway, Eſquire, did the Vintners, to the Rebels, to the quite overthrow of thoſe parts; So as the ſaid Berisford, (to ſave his Ironworkes) perſwaded the ſtrength of Colrain, and the Britiſh thereabouts, to garriſon at Garvagh, a poore thatched Village without defence, where the thirteenth of Decemb. 1641. they were all ſlaine to a very few, their Armes and Munition loſt, and all that whole Country over-run by fire and Sword, So as the Commiſſioners of Colrain, ſent for my aid, that wanted Match and ſome other proviſion, (though by the right Worthy Mercers providence, had good ſtore of Powder and Armes, in ſo much as I left the Right worthy Mercers Caſtle, with all my goods therein (after I had held it out ſeven weeks and three dayes) with two neere Kinſmen of the Earle of Antrims, (by the advice of the ſaid Commiſſioners) who undertook the ſafety thereof, they then ſeeming not to affect that Rebellion, whoſe Lands are ſufficient to make all good. And thus with no ſmall danger, I brought neere two hundred Britiſh to Colerain, without loſſe of any, where I found them in a ſad condition, yet incouraged them ſo, as wee made up ſeven hundred Foote, and fifty Horſe, And ſet it in a true poſture of defence, after the Diſcipline of the Low Countries, where firſt I was bred; and made ſome Lethar-gunnes, with two peeces of Artillery, at my own charge, And cauſed the weakeſt parts thereof to bee Paliſadoed, and cloſe fights made for ſaving our men, being for ſixteen weekes ſpace begirt in with ſome five thouſand Rebells, ſo as our duties proved extreame, and Peſtilence with Famine, tooke ſome thouſands to the grave, many dying in their own Ordure, up and down the ſtreets. Beſides all other our Loſſes, Croſſes, and dyſaſters, through treacherous, wilfull and perverſe Counſells and dealings, ſome of the beſt and neereſt to the ſaid Berisford, favouring thoſe Iriſh too much, as ever hee did, yet wee held it out till about the ſeventeenth of October following, that news came thither that wee were all caſt, and new men entred the ſame to our terrible loſſe, and diſparagement, being all the Engliſh Tenants, of your own planting, that was thereabouts left alive, by that Maſſacre, able to beare Armes; And is like never to bee recovered, but by a true ſetled Government,
in a brotherly way. But not thus compelled to part with our birth-right, and all our poſſeſſions, for leſſe then a meſſe of Pottage, after ſo high deſervings, as to Raiſe, Arme, Horſe, Cloathe, and maintain ſo many men, for ſo long a time, with that ſaved from thoſe Rebels, upon the onely incouragements of this Honourable Parliament, That may it pleaſe you for their honours, maturely to conſider that thoſe Towns, and eſpecially Colerain, that coſt you ſo much, being but deſired for their garriſon, upon needfull occaſions of retreat, when footing with ſafety was ſcarce thought there to bee had, will bee the better ſpared now, there is ſo much roome, as not a conſiderable party of Enemies doth remaine within ſome hundred miles of that place, or in all Ulſter, unleſſe ſome ſew at Dongannon, and Charlimount, that is farre from it. And eſpecially now three thouſand of that new Army, of the ten thouſand Scots, hath left that Kingdome ſo long ſince, ſo as they there yet remain with the reſt of thoſe old Forces, may purſue the Enemy, as hereafter mentioned, for which purpoſe they have their pay, and the reſt by due Government, may raiſe what profits there is to bee made for the better ſupply and reliefe of them; and the eaſe and ſafety to all Britaine, as extreame neceſſity now requireth. Your Honours Petitioner for thoſe Commanders, yet unſatisfyed any thing, doe deſire now that allowed by the Parliament may bee ſent them, it beeing ſo little and long time due; And that thoſe other Britiſh with himſelfe, and Sonnes, there planted by this Honourable City of London, may bee favoured and imployed, but as to Law, Reaſon and Juſtice ſhall ſeem meet.

closer.signed: And Your Honours Petitioner ſhall duly pray, &c.

div.head: To the Right Worſhipfull Committee of Adventurers for Land in Jreland. The humble Propoſitions and Petition of Thomas Church.
div.p: VVHereas the Agents for thoſe Armies, are content with a third part of pay for all their Commanders, to the Sergeants; and the reſt with half pay and cloathing; You may be pleaſed to procure a ſelect Committee of your owne, to raiſe Proviſions, there to maintain 20000 at the leaſt, by ſending (with the Ordinance therefore) your Aſſurance by fit men, That what each Pariſh, or party, now do give, lend, or adventure, for Lands in Ireland, ſhall bee imployed towards regaining the ſame, and no otherwiſe. And that a due Record thereof ſhall remaine with you, for them and their poſterity, to bee ſatisfied therein upon all occaſions, that by a ſetled and conſtant courſe, meanes for thoſe Armies may bee in a perfect readineſſe, and one quarters pay, at the leaſt alwaies there under ſafe cuſtody to be delivered as you ſhall appoint, from the time you begin.

Secondly, That two Commiſſaries of known truſt and skill bee imployed thither, (that hath no relation to any of thoſe Commanders,) with other Commiſſioners there appointed, to recrute all thoſe Troops moſt fit for War, and Field-ſervice, into hundreds, (beſides the Captains and Lieutenants) and each like Foot Company into 90 Muſquettiers, and 60 Pikes, (beſides Officers) with the reſt that are not ſo convenient, and eight of thoſe Companies to a Regiment. To the taking away much danger, and all unneceſſary charge. And then paid and ſo continued.

Thirdly, That each Commiſſary may have power from time to
time to call to their aſſiſtance ſuch chiefe men of truſt, (not belonging to any thoſe Armies) as thoſe places ſhall afford, where they ſhall take their Muſters in, that the Accounts thereof bee certifyed under other mens hands, as well as their owne; And that they ſee the Souldiers have that allowed them by the State, and doe exactly muſter once every halfe yeere, all other the Britiſh inhabitants there, from fifteen to threeſcore yeeres of age, that their ſtrength bee truely known, and ordered accordingly, and that they have power to command their guard from place to place about thoſe affaires.

Fourthly, That no man do muſter for a Souldier in other name then his own upon paine of death, and checke to ſuch Officers of all their meanes then due, as ſhall ſo attempt, and that every Governour and Aſſiſtant doe take ſpeciall care herein, and that thoſe Armies bee diſpatched to the Field in all convenient time, to cleare as they goe, and live by the enemies ſpoyles, and Garriſon themſelves ſo neare their Coaſts, as to bee with them upon all occaſions.

Fifthly, Whereas no people can bee truely happy, without a due ſetled Government, that for every conſiderable place there, a Governour bee appointed, with twelve more of the beſt affected Britiſh within their ſeverall Precincts, upon all fitting occaſions, to rule by Marſhall Law during pleaſure, that offenders bee reclaimed or cut off, and the Subject cheriſhed, and incouraged to all manner of good husbandry, and Tillage, and drawn into Liſt, from fifteen, to threeſcore yeeres of age, under fitting Commanders, for the better ſafety both of Town and Country; And that every Governour have his Provoſt Marſhall with twenty men or leſſe, as need ſhall require, to guard and keep their ſeverall precincts, from Rebels, Theeves, and oppreſſors, and do preſerve all Woods and Fiſhings, and that all ſuch Governours do every halfe yeere give in their ſeveral Accounts, that a true Record therof may bee had in either Kingdom without deniall to any, whom it may concern, and do referre their pay to their ſeverall deſervings.

Sixthly, that to the Government of London-derry, and thoſe Liberties with the two next Baronies belonging thereto, of Kenaugh, and Bainhur, bee laid, The two next Baronies of Eniſhowne, and Strabane, and to the Government of the Town and Liberties
of Colraine, and that Baronie with the Baronie of Loughinſolin bee laid, the two next Baronies on Antrim ſide, the River of Bann, from the Sea towards Loughbeg, and the rather for that it was ſo determined, for the eaſe, ſafety, and good of thoſe parts, when his Majeſtie by his Commiſſioners, entred on thoſe Lands and Revenues, which belonged to the Honorable City of London; and that they, with you, have the nomination of Governours there too, in regard of their great care, and vaſt expence thereon, for the generall good, and ſetling of your plantations together.

Seventhly, That every Governour within their ſeverall Precincts towards the better maintenance of thoſe warres, have power to raiſe all profits and Commodities of Lands, Rents, Fiſhings, and Cuſtomes, in a faire and indifferent way, and to call all ſuch to account, as have received the like, ſince the beginning of thoſe warres: And what thoſe Armies or any part of them have taken or received from any of thoſe Britiſh Plantationers, to goe on in their pay, That the true Owners thereof, with the Creditors, and oppreſſed, bee ſatisfyed in Lands or Monies, and not driven from their own, as they have been, but rather allowed all other their loſſes out of thoſe Rebels Lands; and that upon Wine, Aquavitae, and Tobacco, Exciſe bee ſet for the more eaſe to England, all that may bee.

Eighthly, That no Governour, Officer, or Aſſiſtant, bee admitted into that ſervice, or ſuffered to continue therein, that hath, or ſhall have any unlawfull dealings with any of thoſe Rebels, ſince their rebelling, or that hath colourable intereſts in any of their Lands, or given to pervert Juſtice, Or that hath ſlightly and careleſly loſt or given up into any of their hands, any City, Town, Caſtle, or ſtrong Hold: But that ſuch, and all Rebels Lands bee found out by all due meanes, and by each Governour, preſented to this Committee, That the King may bee rightly ſtated in all, that is loſt by that Rebellion, and each Lord of Lands, and the Adventurers have their right, And that no Cattell whatſoever bee tranſported out of Ireland, upon pain of puniſhment, and forfeiting the ſame, with ſuch Barkes and Boats, as ſhall ſo preſume.

Ninthly, That every ſitting Congregation have a ſufficient Preaching Miniſter, with reaſonable allowance where thoſe livings will not maintain them, but the malignant and ill-living Miniſter
to bee diſcharged. And the Ordinance for ſwearing, drunkenneſſe, and profaning the Lords Sabbath, bee put in due execution there.

Tenthly, That ſome prime Officers and Governours have power to protect all ſuch Iriſh that by their Papiſticall Lords, Prieſts, and Gentry, have been cauſed to rebell, and will ſhew their repentance worthy of life, by their true carriage, and ſervice doing on the reſt, That upon ſettlement they may have pardons in new ſirnames, to the quite extirpating all their old rebellious names and Cepts; which being rightly ordered, will draw them into a religious obedience, to the ſaving much blood and treaſure, and ſoon gaining that Land, with the Commodities thereof.

Eleventhly, That you will bee pleaſed to take into your ſpeciall conſideration, the true worth of Sir William Cole of Eniskillin, to bee Governour of London-Derry, and the foure Baronies thereto, as formerly mentioned, though my acquaintance is no otherwiſe of him, than from a long continued report of his Valour, and integrity to Juſtice, that hath been well tryed ſince that laſt rebellion, who doubtleſſe will ſtand the State, and You, with all of thoſe parts, in moſt ſingular good ſtead, for the generall good.

And whereas your Petitioner, with his foure ſonnes, loſt great eſtates by that Rebellion, beſides debts and goods of much value, yet upon this Honourable Parliaments incouragements, did raiſe two hundred choyce Britiſh Foot, and fifty Horſe, wherewith they did good ſervice, to the ſaving of Colraine, &c. as hath been truely proved, but were caſt through your troubles here, with no more allowed us for ſome ten Moneths pay, then 170 pound; Though your Petitioner ſpent thereon 1365 pound, whereby wee are made deepe Adventurers to the ruine of us all, if not timely prevented.

May it therefore pleaſe you to imploy either of your petitioners Sonnes as Commiſſary for Ʋlſter, and himſelfe Governour of Colraine, and thoſe foure Baronies, as formerly mentioned, for the more perfect effecting theſe ſervices to the life.
div.closer: And Your Honours Petitioner ſhall duly pray, &c.
